contextId.information: Yahweh is saying he will protect Jerusalem and compares his protection to a wall of fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: become for her a wall of fire around her

contextId.information: Their cities have already been destroyed and are left open for people to steal anything they would like. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and they will be plunder

contextId.information: "Yahweh will make Judah his personal portion of the holy land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will inherit ... in the holy land

contextId.information: A brand is a piece of burning wood that is removed from a fire before it is completely burned up. This refers to Joshua, who was rescued from captivity in Babylon and returned to Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a brand pulled from the fire

contextId.information: This is a poetic way of saying, "men anointed (that is, chosen)." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the sons of fresh olive oil

contextId.information: AT: "they were like cattle that refused to be yoked" or "they were like cattle that refused to obey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: set their shoulders stubbornly

contextId.information: AT: "I will scatter them as a whirlwind scatters leaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will scatter them with a whirlwind

contextId.information: God is speaking about himself as if he were an army. AT: "I will protect my land" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will camp around my land

contextId.information: This pit represents the exile. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the pit where there is no water

contextId.information: The people of Judah are referred to as if they were a bow carried by God into battle. AT: "I will use the people of Judah to fight against the people of Greece" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: bent Judah as my bow

contextId.information: AT: "will completely defeat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will devour

contextId.information: "Shepherds" represents the leaders of God's people. AT: "My anger toward the shepherds of my people is strong" or "I am very angry with the leaders of my people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My wrath burns against the shepherds

contextId.information: "The cornerstone will come from them." An important ruler is spoken of as if he there the main foundation stone of a building. AT: "Some of their descendants will be very important rulers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: From them will come the cornerstone

contextId.information: "the war bow will come from them." Military leaders are spoken of as if they were the bow that was used in battle. AT: "the military leaders will come from them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: from them will come the war bow

contextId.information: Scripture often refers to the sea as an image of many troubles and hardships. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will pass through the sea of their affliction

contextId.information: AT: "they will have no mercy on the land's people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they will destroy the land

contextId.information: That is, the drink is alcoholic and will cause the armies attacking Jerusalem to become drunk and unable to fight. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: causing all the peoples surrounding her to stagger about

contextId.information: "something impossible to move" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: heavy stone for all the peoples

contextId.information: "will destroy the surrounding peoples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will consume all the surrounding peoples

contextId.information: "The flock" refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the flock

contextId.information: Metal is passed through fire in order to purify or harden it. This expression serves here as a metaphor for exposing the people to suffering in order that they may become more faithful to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will bring that third through the fire
